Heineken Prize for Medicine 2008 awarded to Sir Richard Peto | journal = Nederlands tijdschrift voor geneeskunde | volume = 152 | issue = 41 | pages = 2216–2218 | year = 2008 | pmid = 19009807 }} | influences = [[Richard Doll]] }} '''Sir Richard Peto''' [[Fellow of the Royal Society|FRS]] (born 14 May 1943) is Professor of Medical [[Statistics]] and [[Epidemiology]] at the [[University of Oxford]], [[England]].{{Cite journal | last1 = Mann | first1 = C.| title = Richard Peto: Statistician with a Mission | doi = 10.1126/science.249.4968.479 | journal = Science | volume = 249 | issue = 4968 | pages = 479–426| year = 1990 | pmid = 17735279| pmc =| url = http://www.legacy.library.ucsf.edu/tid/mwr78e00| accessdate = 2012-08-07}} He attended [[Taunton's School]] in [[Southampton]] and subsequently studied [[Natural Sciences]] at [[Queens' College, Cambridge|Queens' College]], [[University of Cambridge|Cambridge University]]. His career has included important collaborations with [[Richard Doll]] beginning at the [[Medical Research Council (UK)|Medical Research Council]] Statistical Research Unit in [[London]]. He set up the [[Clinical Trial Service Unit]] (CTSU) in [[Oxford]] in 1975 and is currently co-director. He was made a [[Fellow of the Royal Society]] in 1989 for his contributions to the development of [[meta-analysis]]. He is a leading expert on deaths related to [[tobacco]] use. He was knighted for his services to epidemiology and to cancer prevention in 1999, and he received an honorary Doctor of Medical Sciences degree from [[Yale University]] in 2011.{{cite web|title=Sir Richard Peto|url=http://www.cardioscience.ox.ac.uk/bhf-centre-of-research-excellence/researcher-profiles/sir-richard-peto|publisher=University of Oxford|accessdate=26 December 2012}} {{cite web|title=Yale University: Honorary Degrees|url=http://ris-systech2.its.yale.edu/hondegrees/hondegrees.asp|publisher=[[Yale University]]|location=USA|accessdate=26 December 2012}} His brother [[Julian Peto]], with whom he has published work in mathematical statistics (e.g. on the [[logrank test]]), is also a distinguished epidemiologist. His family runs a [[Thai cuisine|Thai]] restaurant in Oxford's [[Covered Market, Oxford|Covered Market]], of whose parent company he is a director.{{cite web|title=Sasi's Thai|url=http://listings.findthecompany.co.uk/l/167620808/Sasi-s-Thai-Ltd-in-Oxford-United-Kingdom|website=Find The Company | location=UK |accessdate=24 May 2015}} [[Peto's paradox]] is named after him. ==References== {{reflist}} ==Selected publications== * Gribbin B, Pickering TG, Sleight P, Peto R.
